bibl.note: This document is a letter written by Charles Harris to James Trimble in 1823. In the letter, Harris discusses with Trimble a lawsuit that he is involved in over land he owns in Tennessee.

div.p:
I received ⁁ a letter from you containing a formula with a plan of instrutions instructions relative to a mischievious mischievous lawsuit of a Land affair that my name is affixed to in your State — I know so little of the origin & progress of the lawsuit that I have no data to go upon in my mind to decide whether I should approve or disapprove of the conduct & management of the affair — The thing appeared to me in the origin that there were nothing but self evident truth, to act with & upon — But like an erratic figure in a sum of Arithmatic Arithmetic no matter however ho where it may be placed but I suppose the newer the begining beginning the greater will be the divergence from
truth in the result —

Thomas Harris has refered to sign join with me in the probate you have sent on the solid presumtion presumption that he never knew any thing relative to the ⁁ affair
untill until I acquainted him by a letter from Mr Campbell that his name was joined with mine in this waful Lawsuit he immediately gave me a reliage and quit claim — I was no how aware this would ever be farther necessary than merely to promote our mutual satisfaction — I herewith inclose his retiafe — with all the requisite authorities that I could find were necessary —

Jane Alexander is so religiously
melancholly melancholy that nothing can be done with her in the affairs of the sublunory would her business appears to be taken at last ostensibly with the concerns of the undiscovered
county — For Matter of merely being against whatever might be surmised — I got a release from her and all her grown children at or bout the same time Thomas Harris executed his —
I hereby enclose a letter from Johnson — & Calhoun the younger from which I am told by my friend Julius Alexander you may draw some precious confessions
